You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 702, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the dimensions of a boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 445, 106]]<|/det|>
The apparatus has been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 576, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 144, 680, 350]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 363, 532, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 144, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 394, 611, 413]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(3 \mathrm{cm}^3\) of water into the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 425, 796, 444]]<|/det|>
Measure the height \(h_0\) of the water level from the bench, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 456, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h_0 =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** precaution that is taken when measuring the height of the water level to ensure the reading is accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 589, 537]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 641, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Using the dropping pipette, and measuring cylinder if necessary, add a further volume of water \(V = 5.0 \text{cm}^3\) to the water already in the boiling tube. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 856, 135]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the new height \(h\) of the water level from the bench. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure, adding \(5.0 \text{cm}^3\) of water each time so that the total volume of water added \(V = 10.0 \text{cm}^3\), \(15.0 \text{cm}^3\), \(20.0 \text{cm}^3\) and \(25.0 \text{cm}^3\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 197, 541, 214]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 222, 650, 375]]<|/det|>
\(V/\text {cm}^{3}\)\(h/\text {cm}\)\(H/\text {cm}\)
5.0
10.0
15.0
20.0
25.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 394]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 407, 146, 425]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 407, 920, 456]]<|/det|> For each value of \(V,\) calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the increase in height \(H\) of the water in the boiling tube. Use your value of \(h_0\) from (a), the values of \(h\) in Table 1.1 and the equation \(H = (h - h_0)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 594, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 675, 900, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 897, 212]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of the colour of the outside surface of replace the lid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 455, 440]]<|/det|> Place the thermometer in the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 920, 485]]<|/det|> In the first row of Table 2.1, water at \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 510, 548]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 623, 541, 641]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 650, 791, 892]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Write a conclusion stating if the colour of the outside surface of the beaker affects the rate of cooling of the water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 653, 121]]<|/det|>
Justify your answer by reference to values from your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 257, 180, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 257, 920, 272]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) for the water in beaker A during the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 274, 719, 293]]<|/det|>
Use your readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 304, 559, 336]]<|/det|>
\[x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 346, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 378, 485, 396]]<|/det|>
Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 439, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<form>x<sub>A</sub> = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 471, 180, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 470, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\) for the water in beaker B during the experiment. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 517, 559, 549]]<|/det|>
\[x_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 560, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 592, 329, 609]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 653, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{\mathrm{B}} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>

In the space provided, draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor.

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
The current in the circuit can be controlled by connecting a range of different resistors in place of resistors P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
State one disadvantage of this method instead of using a variable resistor to control the current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 439, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 826, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of temperature on the bounce height of a squash ball. A squash ball is a hollow rubber ball approximately 4 cm in diameter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the bounce height of the ball changes as the temperature of the ball rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 522, 183]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 398, 214]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 378, 229]]<|/det|>
· a selection of squash balls

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 479, 245]]<|/det|>
· standard laboratory heating equipment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 596, 260]]<|/det|>
· a beaker large enough for the squash ball to fit inside

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 343, 276]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 290, 324, 307]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 457, 338]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions to ensure reliable results (you may draw a diagram below if it helps to explain your plan)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 507, 416]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 430, 834, 463]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 606, 494]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
